video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: - [Voiceover] Organisms that reproduce sexually have got to get their genes together somehow. To do this, they package their genetic material

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: into specialized cells called sex cells. This is the sperm cell. Its the sex cell of the male.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: The sole purpose of the sperm, the entire reason for its existence, is to transfer the males genetic material

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: into the female sex cell or the egg. So the sperm cell is packed with features that allow it to fulfill its job.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Its basically a little torpedo. You can see, just like a torpedo, it has a pointed head which allows it

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: to travel in the forward direction. At the back end it has the tail, and the tail is just a flagellum,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and as the flagellum spins it acts like a little propeller. And then it has a middle section. Now within that middle section,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: wrapped around the base of the flagellar tail, are all of these little organelles called mitochondria. You can see Im drawing these mitochondria

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: wrapped around the flagellar base here. And mitochondria are organelles that are responsible for giving energy to a cell.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And the sperm cell has a whole bunch packed right into the base of the flagellum here. Probably 75 to 100, and theyre quite large mitochondria.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: In fact, these mitochondria are often fused together to create big organelles. And the reason is because in order to propel

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: the sperm torpedo towards the egg, it needs a lot of energy. And that all comes from these mitochondria.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Now the payload of the torpedo is here in the head, and thats the genetic material, our DNA within the nucleus. Ill draw it kind of all coiled back here.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And heres the nuclear envelope here. And just like any regular torpedo, the sperm torpedo has a warhead right in the front.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And that warhead is a little collection of enzymes called the acrosome. And the acrosome is gonna be important

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: later on for fertilization. But thats pretty much it. Theres a tail at the back to provide propulsion,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: some mitochondria in the middle section to give energy to the tail, a head which contains the nuclear material,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and the acrosome. This is a pretty bare bones cell. Its designed to move fast and to get to the egg.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: There are no bells and whistles here. Now thats in contrast to the egg cell. Now the first thing youll notice

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: is that the egg cell is round, unlike the torpedo shape of the sperm cell. This is not a cell thats made for active mobility.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: The second thing is that the egg cell is huge compared to the sperm cell. Its so big, in fact, that its almost visible.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: In fact, sometimes it is visible to the human eye. Now compared to the sperm cell, which Ill draw in here, the egg cell is about 10,000 times more massive.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And similar to the sperm cell, the egg cell has its share of genetic material ready to combine during fertilization.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: You can see it here within the nucleus. And so you may have noticed this thick outer coating on the egg cell here,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: thats a very important structure called the zona pellucida. And the zona pellucida is a thick layer of glycoproteins that sit on the outside of the egg.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And glycoproteins are basically a protein, Ill draw a protein here in green, with a whole bunch of branching sugar chains

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: that are coming off of them. And so what this looks like is basically a little tree or a long branching thing thats growing out

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: of the edge of the egg cell. And theres a whole bunch of them, and they form this very thick kind of protective layer

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: that the sperm has to get through. And the edge of the egg cell is the actual plasma membrane. And once the sperm can deliver

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: its genetic material beyond that, fertilization has occurred. Now theres a whole bunch of other structures

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: within the egg cytoplasm as well. And remember this thing is huge. And Im gonna draw in a few here in green.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Now what Im drawing in are actually more mitochondria. Now remember the egg cell had 75 to 100 big mitochondria right at the base of the flagellum

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: to provide energy to drive locomotion. Well, the egg cell has mitochondria too. Its got a lot of other different organelles as well.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: But the egg cell is so large, its got somewhere between 100 and 200 thousand mitochondria present. So keep those mitochondria in mind, well talk

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: about them a little bit later in the next section. So now that youve met the two major players here, the sperm and the egg, or the male and female

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: sex cells respectively, we can talk about what happens when they meet. And that process is called fertilization.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: So well go ahead and label our egg down here. And well put a quick label on this as well. This is the zona pellucida that we talked about earlier.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: So well draw the sperm here coming in to meet the egg. Well draw its tail. Well draw its middle section here.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And well draw its torpedo-like head here. Get rid of all this zona pellucida glycoprotein in the middle here.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Now here are the mitochondria in the middle section here, and we have the genetic material payload of our sperm torpedo here in the back,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and our acrosome here in the front. Now the first thing that happens during fertilization is that the sperm comes into contact

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: with the zona pellucida. And the zona pellucida actually binds to the outside of the sperm,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and thats called sperm binding. And its step number one. Now what happens when the sperm gets bound

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: to the zona pellucida is that that sets up a reaction called the acrosomal reaction. So step number two is called the acrosome reaction.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And that little warhead tip of the sperm torpedo gets released, and so we have all of the acrosomal enzymes that were sitting in the head that just kind of leak out

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: into that zona pellucida. And as those enzymes leak out, they actually start to digest away the zona pellucida.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Here you can see Im kind of eating away here at those glycoprotein, and that allows the sperm head to dive in deeper

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: towards our plasma membrane. Now as the sperm gets closer to the plasma membrane of the egg, and it comes in contact right here,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: it starts up a process of binding. The two touch and they come together. And as they start together, it causes another reaction,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and that third reaction is called cortical reaction. And what I havent drawn here is another structure in the egg,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and those structures are right underneath the plasma membrane, and they just sit there waiting.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And they wait and their entire job is to wait for a sperm to bind. And as soon as a single sperm binds,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: they get ejected out into that zone pellucida as well. Just like the acrosomal enzymes, these enzymes that are contained

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: within the cortical granules also start eating away at the zona pellucida. These enzymes eat away, and they dissolve and chew up

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: these glycoproteins, but specifically they chew up the glycoprotein that allows sperm to bind. So at this point we have a single sperm thats bound,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: set off the cortical reaction, and these cortical granules are released that chew up all the other places

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: that more sperm can bind. So as our other sperm torpedoes are coming in, theyre just bouncing off.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: They hit the glycoproteins, but the one that they need to bind to isnt there because its all been chewed up and degraded by these cortical granules.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: So thats actually called a block to polyspermy. Now thats a very important concept. Polyspermy is a term that just means multiple sperm.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And what we dont want is for more than one sperm to inject its nuclear material, its DNA into this egg. What youd end up with is an egg

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: with a single contribution from mom and then one or two or three or 100 contributions or genetic material from dad.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And that would never work, youd end up with all sorts of problems as the egg started to divide. Occasionally, that does happen,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and it can result in a zygote that fails. But for the most part, as these cortical granules dissolve away all the sperm binding glycoproteins

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: of the zona pellucida, other sperm just cant get in and they bounce off as they arrive. So now we have a sperm thats made its way

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: all the way to the plasma membrane of our egg cell. Its started to bind to the plasma membrane, the acrosome is gone, Ill erase that here.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Its done its job. The cortical granules have been released, and theyre preventing other sperm from getting in.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: And we start to actually fuse our plasma membranes of our sperm cell and our egg cell. And that allows for this entire structure to come in.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: All of the genetic material here within the, all of the genetic material within the nucleus of the sperm cell can start to come out

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and get released here into the egg. And once we have fusion of genetic material, that is fertilization.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: So just to recap, well go back to look at our close-up of our sperm. We can see that its a very mobile structure

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: evolved basically to get genetic material from the male to the female egg cell. Its got a tail that propulses it,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: its got mitochondria that feed it energy, its got a head with a payload of nuclear material and an acrosome warhead on the tip.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: The egg cell is a giant cell by comparison. Its got a specialized layer of glycoproteins on the outside that have a bunch of specialized features

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: and then a bunch of cytoplasm, including mitochondria. And then the process of egg meeting sperm itself is called fertilization.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Sperm binds to the zona pellucida, the glycoproteins, you have an acrosomal reaction, and then a cortical reaction prevents

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: more than one sperm getting in. And then material, the genetic material of the sperm is transferred.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Now youll notice here that I drew the genetic material from the nucleus coming in. Now some of you may be wondering,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: "Well dont mitochondria have genetic material as well?" Well, thats true. Mitochondria do have mitochondrial DNA. And potentially, some of these mitochondria

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: can get sucked in during that genetic transfer process as well. But remember, our egg cell had

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: 100 to 200 thousand mitochondrial copies, and our sperm cell only had 75 to 100. Now theres a little bit of debate,

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: but in the end the male contributes essentially no mitochondria to the zygote thats formed after the egg and sperm fuse.

video.subject: SCIENCE
video.text: Now, it could be that some of those mitochondria actually do make their way in and then are degraded.
